audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 26, Lesson 1. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Books for Unit 25 and Unit 26.

Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 9 in your Unit 25 Student Book. Whisper read the story “Trading for This and That.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Blend Words: Now that we’ve learned about the schwa sound, let’s blend some words with this sound to practice what we have learned. Listen as I sound out the first two words.

/əəəssslllēēēp/, asleep. /əəəbooowwwt/, about. Now read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether’. Say the word nice and loud.
Review Phonics Cards
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster.
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Review Word Cards
Let’s review some words. Say the word for each high-frequency word card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster. I’ll mix the cards.
Find the card for the word I say. Listen carefully.
Multimodal mini-lesson. Listen to the sound.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the pocket chart and word>

audio.transcription: articulation video TK
This is the sound-spelling card for the schwa sound. The schwa sound is pronounced “uh,” as in the second syllable of "carrot." This sound can be spelled with any vowel—a, e, i, o, u.
audio.notes: <visual: show the sound-spelling card for schwa>

audio.transcription: When a multisyllabic word begins with "a" as the first syllable, the letter "a" makes the schwa, or “uh,” sound. Listen as I read the following word: "a" <pause> "sleep" <pause> "asleep."
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "asleep" with the letter "a" in red>

audio.transcription: Practice reading the following words with the schwa sound.

Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about Dutch “tulip fever”. First, look at the graph and picture. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. graph <pause>, date <pause>, tulip. Look at the graph. What does this graph show?
Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about Dutch “tulip fever”. The word is disrupted. When something is disrupted it is stopped or kept from continuing.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, disrupted>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words disrupted and spiked>

audio.transcription: Now listen to “Tulip Fever.”
Do you have any wonderings or questions about Dutch “tulip fever”? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 1 in your Unit 26 Student Book. The title of this story is "The Great Pet Swap.” Point to each word as you read the title with me: The Great Pet Swap. This story is realistic fiction. It has characters like people you know, and events that could happen in real life.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this story: result. A result is an effect of doing something. The win was a result of the team’s extra practice. What is one result of recycling plastic instead of throwing it away?
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story and the word, result>

audio.transcription: Read the story. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Find a word in the third paragraph that has the schwa sound.
What happens as a result of the pet swap? Find the sentences that answer the question.
How are Michael and Sarah’s experiences with each other’s pets the same? How are they different?
Have you ever cared for someone else’s pet? What was it like?
You can reread this story during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.
Write to Deepen Comprehension: Write what happens on the walk with Goliath and Oscar. <pause> Share your ideas with a partner before you write. Look back at the story for ideas.

toc.title: Build Phonemic Awareness: Add Initial and Final Sounds

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 26, Lesson 2. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 26.

Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 1 in your Unit 26 Student Book. Whisper read the story “The Great Pet Swap.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Let's learn some high-frequency words. We will Say, Spell, Read, and Write each word.
audio.notes: <visual: e-pocket chart with the following words in this order: ago, government, half, machine, pair.>

audio.transcription: Let's start with the word half. Say the word with me. Half. Which sounds do you hear in half? (/h/ /a/ /f/)
What letters to you see? (h-a-l-f). The letter l in half is silent, so we have to remember that when we spell the word.
Now write the word. Say each letter as you write it.
Now let's Say, Spell, Read, and Write these words: ago, government, machine, pair.

slides.title: Build Phonemic Awareness: Add Initial and Final Sounds

audio.transcription: Listen as I say a word: at. <slight pause> Now, listen as I say a sound: /ch/
Add the sound /ch/ to the beginning of the word at. What's the new word? <pause> chat
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words and sounds.
Now let's add a sound to the end of a word. Listen as I say a word: pin. <slight pause> Now, listen as I say a sound: /ch/
Add the sound /ch/ to the end of the word pin. What's the new word? <pause> pinch
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words and sounds.

This is the sound-spelling card for the schwa sound. The schwa sound is pronounced “uh,” as in the second syllable of "carrot." This sound can be spelled with any vowel—a, e, i, o, u. Listen to the following words that have a schwa sound: "asleep," "camel," "family," "upon."
audio.notes: <visual: show the sound-spelling card for schwa>

audio.transcription: Write the schwa spellings several times. Say the "uh" sound each time you write the spelling.
Blend Words: Now that we’ve learned about the schwa sound, let’s blend some words with this sound to practice what we have learned. Listen as I sound out the first two words.

/əəəssslllēēēp/, asleep. /əəəbooowwwt/, about. Now read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether’. Say the word nice and loud.

Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about why schools have summer vacations. First, look at these four pictures. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. school <pause>, students <pause>, tent <pause>, campfire <pause>, pool <pause>, swimsuit <pause>, bicycles. Look at the picture of the campfire. What are the people in the picture using the campfire for?
Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about why schools have summer vacations. The word is absent. Absent means “missing.”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, absent>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words absent and switch>

audio.transcription: Now listen to “Why Do Schools Have Summer Vacation?”
Do you have any wonderings or questions about why schools have summer vacations? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 2 in your Unit 26 Student Book. The title of this text is "In Season.” Point to each word as you read the title with me: In Season. This comic is about fruits and vegetables and when they’re in season. There are speech bubbles for each fruit and vegetable speaking.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this text: export. Export means “to ship and sell goods to another country.” The prefix ex- means “out,” so these goods are taken out of our country. China and India export tea to countries around the world. What does the United States export to other countries?
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story and the word, export>

audio.transcription: Read the text. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Find the words that name the vegetables on the first page of the story.
Which countries export bananas? Find the sentence that answers the question.
Why do we get some foods from different places around the world? Summarize.
Which food in this text do you like best? Why?
You can reread this text during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.
Write to Deepen Comprehension: List when and where different fruits and vegetables grow. <pause> Draw a picture to accompany your list.
Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 26, Lesson 3. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 26.
Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 2 in your Unit 26 Student Book. Whisper read the story “In Season.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Review Phonics Cards
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster.
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Review Word Cards
Let’s review some words. Say the word for each high-frequency word card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster. I’ll mix the cards.
Find the card for the word I say. Listen carefully.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the pocket chart and word>

audio.transcription: This is the sound-spelling card for the schwa sound. The schwa sound is pronounced “uh,” as in the second syllable of "carrot." This sound can be spelled with any vowel—a, e, i, o, u. Listen to the following words that have a schwa sound: "asleep," "camel," "family," "upon."
audio.notes: <visual: show the sound-spelling card for schwa>

audio.transcription: Write the schwa spellings several times. Say the "uh" sound each time you write the spelling.

Blend Words: Now that we’ve learned about the schwa sound, let’s blend some words with this sound to practice what we have learned. Read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether.’ Say the word nice and loud.
Let's find and circle all the words beginning with /ə/.
Now, let's put a box around all the words with suffixes.
Blending Focus: Use your letter cards to build each word I say. Let's start by doing one together. Make the word live. <pause> Add a to the beginning. What word did you make? Alive
Listen carefully as your teacher tells you the letter or letters to change to make the next word with your letter cards.

Let's build this set of words again. This time your teacher will not tell you which letters to change. Let's try one together: Make the word live.<pause>. Now change live to alive. Which sound is different? Which letter will be different?

Build Words Booster: Let's do some more word building. Listen carefully as your teacher tells you which word to make with your letter cards. Your teacher will check your work. Think about each sound in the word you are making. Use letter cards to spell the word.
audio.notes: <visual: show the letter cards to build the words>

audio.transcription: Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 3 in your Unit 26 Student Book. Today we are going to read some cumulative sentences. These sentences contain words with schwa /ə/ and other phonics skills we have learned. Let’s whisper read one sentence at a time. When you are done, we will chorally read them together.
Circle all the words with schwa /ə/. <pause> Turn to a partner and read the words. Your teacher will listen in.
Write a sentence using the word asleep. <pause> When you are finished, read your sentence to a partner.
audio.notes: <visual: show sentence strips and word asleep>

audio.transcription: Write a sentence using each of these word pairs: attempt/apart, lemon/banana.
audio.notes: <visual: show sentence strips and word pairs attempt/apart, lemon/banana>

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 26, Lesson 4. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 26.
Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 3 in your Unit 26 Student Book. Whisper read the cumulative sentences.
Introduce High-Frequency Words. Let's learn some high-frequency words. We will Say, Spell, Read, and Write each word.
audio.notes: <visual: e-pocket chart with the following words in this order: quickly, scientist, thousand, understood, wait>

audio.transcription: Let's start with the word understood. Say the word with me. Understood. The word "understood" does not follow the rules. Clap and say the syllables in understood (un der stood).
Spell the word with me and let's focus on the spelling of each part of the word separately: un, u-n; der d-e-r; stood, s-t-o-o-d.
Now write the word. Say each letter as you write it.
Now let's Say, Spell, Read, and Write these words: quickly, scientist, thousand, wait.

Listen to each word your teacher says. Write the word. If you need help, tap the sounds or use your sound boxes and counters to break up the word sound by sound. Then think about the letter that stands for each sound.
Let's start with these two words. Write the word annoy.
Now write the word about.
Spelling Booster: Let's write some more words. Listen to each word I say. Break apart the word sound by sound, then write the letter or spelling for each sound.
afford
upon
dozen
parrot
afraid
pizza

This is the sound-spelling card for the schwa sound. The schwa sound is pronounced “uh,” as in the second syllable of "carrot." This sound can be spelled with any vowel—a, e, i, o, u. Listen to the following words that have a schwa sound: "asleep," "camel," "family," "upon."
audio.notes: <visual: show the sound-spelling card for schwa>

audio.transcription: Blend Words: Let’s blend some words to practice what we've learned. Then, read each word as your teacher taps on it.
Select two words from the list. Write a sentence for each word.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 4 in your Unit 26 Student Book. The title of this story is "Tycoon of Tomorrow." Point to each word as you read the title with me: Tycoon of Tomorrow. A tycoon is someone who is successful at business. Read the comic. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Find all the words in the comic with schwa and circle them. <pause> Chorally read the circled words.
Write the sentence I say. Listen carefully and focus on one word at a time.

The first sentence is: Can you adjust the chair so it’s not against the wall? Say the sentence with me: Can you adjust the chair so it’s not against the wall? Now write the sentence. Your teacher will help you segment, or break apart, each word and write a letter for each sound.
The second sentence is: Do you agree that the play was amazing? Say the sentence with me: Do you agree that the play was amazing? Now write the sentence. Your teacher will help you if you need it.
Let's read each sentence out loud. Check your work. Your teacher will write each sentence. Correct your spellings if necessary.

Let's review irregular plural nouns. Remember that a plural noun stands for "more than one of something." Many nouns add "s" or "es" to form the plural. However, some nouns do not. These nouns are irregular.
Some irregular plural nouns can be formed by changing the vowel or vowels in the word. For example, the singular noun "woman" is made plural by changing the "a" to an "e."
audio.notes: <visual: show word card "woman" with a label above it that says "singular" and the word card "women" with a label above it that says "plural">

audio.transcription: Some irregular plural nouns can be formed by changing the "f" or "f-e" in the words to "v-e-s." For example, the plural form of the noun "half" is "halves."
audio.notes: <visual: show word card "half" with a label above it that says "singular" and the word card "halves" with a label above it that says "plural">

audio.transcription: Some irregular plural nouns do not follow any rules. For example, the plural form of the noun "cactus" is "cacti."
audio.notes: <visual: show word card "cactus" with a label above it that says "singular" and the word card "cacti" with a label above it that says "plural">

audio.transcription: Some words, such as "shrimp" do not change when they are plural.
audio.notes: <visual: show word card "shrimp" with a label above it that says "singular" and the word card "shrimp" with a label above it that says "plural">

audio.transcription: Do you know the plural form of these nouns?
Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 26, Lesson 5. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 26.

Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 4 in your Unit 26 Student Book. Whisper read the story “Tycoon of Tomorrow.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Review Phonics Cards
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster.
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Review Word Cards
Let’s review some words. Say the word for each high-frequency word card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster. I’ll mix the cards.
Find the card for the word I say. Listen carefully.
audio.notes: visual: Show the pocket chart and word>

audio.transcription: Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about taxes. First, look at these four pictures. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. trucks <pause>, bridge <pause>, cars <pause>, public library <pause>, public school <pause>, students <pause>, firefighters. Look at the pictures of the public school and public library. What do these two places have in common?
Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about taxes. The word is income. Income is money that is earned from a job.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, income>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words income and percentage>

audio.transcription: Now listen to “Tax Dollars at Work”
Do you have any wonderings or questions about taxes? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 5 in your Unit 26 Student Book. The title of this text is "What Are Taxes?” Point to each word as you read the title with me: What Are Taxes? You will read an informational text about taxes.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this text: submit. Submit means “to turn in.” Jade will submit three paintings to the art show. How do we submit homework in our class?
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story and the word, submit>

audio.transcription: Read the text. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Find the food word in the second paragraph that ends with the schwa sound.
When do U.S. residents need to submit their taxes each year? Find the sentence that answers this question.
How is income tax different from sales taxes? Explain.
Are there any other services that you think our tax money should pay for?
You can reread this text during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.

Write to Deepen Comprehension: Draw four boxes on a sheet of paper. <pause> Write a fact about taxes in each box. <pause> Use these facts to write a one or two sentence summary of the text. Share your summary with a partner before writing.

Let's review irregular plural nouns. Remember that a plural noun stands for "more than one of something." Many nouns add "s" or "es" to form the plural. However, some nouns do not. These nouns are irregular.
audio.notes: <visual: show word card "foot" with a label above it that says "singular" and the word card "feet" with a label above it that says "plural">

audio.transcription: To form the plural of the noun "tooth" the letter "os" must change to "es."
audio.notes: <visual: show word card "tooth" with a label above it that says "singular" and the word card "teeth" with a label above it that says "plural">

audio.transcription: Some irregular plural nouns can be formed by changing the "f" or "f-e" in the words to "v-e-s." For example, the plural form of the noun "leaf" is "leaves."
audio.notes: <visual: show word card "leaf" with a label above it that says "singular" and the word card "leaves" with a label above it that says "plural">

audio.transcription: Some irregular plural nouns do not follow any rules. For example, the plural form of the noun "child" is "children."
audio.notes: <visual: show word card "child" with a label above it that says "singular" and the word card "children" with a label above it that says "plural">

audio.transcription: Some words, such as "deer" do not change when they are plural.
audio.notes: <visual: show word card "deer" with a label above it that says "singular" and the word card "deer" with a label above it that says "plural">

audio.transcription: Do you know the plural form of these nouns?

Look at these words. Let's read the words together: about, afraid, away, comma, idea, circus, airplane, ankle, ape, ancient, bake, leaves. Now look at these two categories, schwa and no schwa.. This is the word about. Read the word with me. <pause> Which category should I put about under? <pause> Yes, "about" goes in the "schwa" category because the word about begins with a schwa sound. With your partner, continue to sort the rest of the words.
audio.notes: <visual: show words about, afraid, away, comma, idea, circus, airplane, ankle, ape, ancient, bake, leaves> <visual: show word about> <visual: show the sorting cards schwa and no schwa in a pocket chart>

audio.transcription: What did you notice about the words in each group?
Schwa is a common sound. You may notice the schwa sound in many words. As we read, let's look for words with the schwa sound.

toc.title: Build Phonemic Awareness: Blend and Segment Multisyllabic Words by Syllable

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 26, Lesson 6. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 26.
Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 5 in your Unit 26 Student Book. Whisper read the text “What Are Taxes?” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.

slides.title: Build Phonemic Awareness: Blend and Segment Multisyllabic Words by Syllable

audio.transcription: Listen as I say the following syllables: a-bout
Repeat the syllables and blend them to make a word. a-bout, about.
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following syllables. Blend the syllables to make a word.
Now we will segment words into syllables. Listen as I say the following word: around
Repeat the word and segment it into the syllables you hear. Around, a-round.
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words. Segment each word into the syllables you hear.

This is the sound-spelling card for the schwa sound. The schwa sound is pronounced “uh,” as in the second syllable of "carrot." This sound can be spelled with any vowel—a, e, i, o, u. Listen to the following words that have a schwa sound: "asleep," "camel," "family," "upon."
audio.notes: <visual: show the sound-spelling card for schwa>

audio.transcription: Write the schwa spellings several times. Say the "uh" sound each time you write the spelling.

Blend Words: Let’s blend some words to practice what we've learned. Say the sound for each letter or spelling as your teacher points to it. Blend the sounds to read the word. Now read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether.’ Say the word nice and loud.
Let's review some high-frequency words. We will Say, Spell, Read, and Write each word.
audio.notes: <visual: e-pocket chart with the following words in this order: ago, government, half, machine, pair, quickly, scientist, thousand, understood, wait.>

audio.transcription: Let's start with the word ago. Say the word with me: "/əˈɡō/"
Spell the word with me: a-g-o . The word "ago" beings with the schwa sound. We have to pay extra attention to remember its spelling.
Now write the word. Say each letter as you write it. Then, use the word in a sentence.
Now let's Say, Spell, Read, and Write these words: ago, government, half, machine, pair, quickly, scientist, thousand, understood, wait.

Build Words Booster: Let's do some more word building. Listen carefully as your teacher tells you which word to make with your letter cards. Your teacher will check your work. Think about each sound in the word you are making. Use letter cards to spell the word.
audio.notes: <visual: show the letter cards to build the words>

audio.transcription: Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 6 in your Unit 26 Student Book. Today we are going to read some cumulative sentences. These sentences contain words with the schwa sound and other phonics skills we have learned. Let’s whisper read one sentence at a time. When you are done, we will chorally read them together.
Circle all the words with the schwa sound. <pause> Turn to a partner and read the words. Your teacher will listen in.
Write a sentence using the word award. <pause> When you are finished, read your sentence to a partner.
audio.notes: visual: show sentence strips and word award>

audio.transcription: Write a sentence using each of these word pairs: adopt/animal, arrive/celebrate.
audio.notes: <visual: show sentence strips and word pairs adopt/animal, arrive/celebrate>

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 26, Lesson 7. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 26.
Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 6 in your Unit 26 Student Book. Whisper read the cumulative sentences. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Review Phonics Cards
Say the sound or sounds for each phonics card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster.
Say the sound or sounds for each phonics card you see.
Review Word Cards
Let’s review some words. Say the word for each high-frequency word card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster. I’ll mix the cards.
Finally, find the card for the word I say. Listen carefully.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the pocket chart and word>

audio.transcription: This is the sound-spelling card for the schwa sound. The schwa sound is pronounced “uh,” as in the second syllable of "carrot." This sound can be spelled with any vowel—a, e, i, o, u. Listen to the following words that have a schwa sound: "asleep," "camel," "family," "upon."
audio.notes: <visual: show the sound-spelling card for schwa>

audio.transcription: Write the schwa spellings several times. Say the "uh" sound each time you write the spelling.

Blend Words: Let’s blend some words to practice what we've learned. Read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether.’ Say the word nice and loud.
Let's review some high-frequency words. We will Say, Spell, Read, and Write each word.
audio.notes: <visual: e-pocket chart with the following words in this order: ago, government, half, machine, pair, quickly, scientist, thousand, understood, wait.>

audio.transcription: Let's start with the word government. Say the word with me: "government"
Spell the word with me: g-o-v-e-r-n-m-e-n-t. The word "government" does not follow the rules. We have to pay extra attention to remember its spelling.
Now write the word. Say each letter as you write it. Then, use the word in a sentence.
Now let's Say, Spell, Read, and Write these words: half, machine, pair, quickly, scientist, thousand, understood, wait.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 7 in your Unit 26 Student Book. The title of this text is "If You Were a Trillionaire." Point to the word as you read the title with me: If You Were a Trillionaire. This text includes a bar graph.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: What do you notice or wonder about when reading the text and looking at the bar graph?
Make a bar graph about a collection of objects sorted into categories, such as coins or colored blocks.
Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 26, Lesson 8. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 26.

Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 7 in your Unit 26 Student Book. Whisper read the text “If You Were a Trillionaire.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.

This is the sound-spelling card for the schwa sound. The schwa sound is pronounced “uh,” as in the second syllable of "carrot." This sound can be spelled with any vowel—a, e, i, o, u. Listen to the following words that have a schwa sound: "asleep," "camel," "family," "upon."
audio.notes: <visual: show the sound-spelling card for schwa>

audio.transcription: Write the schwa spellings several times. Say the "uh" sound each time you write the spelling.

Blend Words: Let’s blend some words to practice what we've learned. Read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether.’ Say the word nice and loud.
Let's find and circle all the words with the schwa /ə/.
Now, let's put a box around all the words that are irregular plural nouns.
Blending Focus: Use your letter cards to build each word I say. Let's start by doing one together. Make the word maze. <pause> Add a to the beginning. What word did you make? Amaze
Listen carefully as your teacher tells you the letter or letters to change to make the next word with your letter cards.

Let's build this set of words again. This time your teacher will not tell you which letters to change. Let's try one together: Make the word trap <pause>. Now change maze to amaze. Which sound is different? Which letter will be different?

Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about thrift shopping. First, look at these four pictures. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. thrift store <pause>, toys <pause>, shoes <pause>, shelf <pause>, clothing. Look at the picture of the thrift store. What items do you recognize?
Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about thrift shopping. The word is expensive. Expensive means “costing a lot of money.”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, expensive>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words expensive and condition>

audio.transcription: Now listen to “Benefits of Thrift Shopping”
Do you have any wonderings or questions about thrift shopping? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 8 in your Unit 26 Student Book. The title of this story is "Alissa's Tag Sale.” Point to each word as you read the title with me: Alissa's Tag Sale. You will read a story about a girl and her mom having a tag sale.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this story: expect. Expect means “to believe that something will happen.” The weather forecast says that our area can expect a lot of rain this weekend. What do you expect to do today after school?
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story and the word, expect>

audio.transcription: Read the story. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Find the name of the main character.
What is a tag sale? Find the sentences that answer the question.
What does Alissa expect from the tag sale? Does it meet her expectations? Explain.
Do you agree that “people love tag sales”? Why or why not?
You can reread this story during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.

Write to Deepen Comprehension: Draw a picture to remember the important details in the story. Label the details, such as room, Alissa, mom, tag sale, games, yoga mat, and stuffed animals. <pause> Use the drawing to retell the main points of the text to a partner. <pause> Then, write your retelling.

Let's review irregular plural nouns. Remember that a plural noun stands for "more than one of something." Many nouns add "s" or "es" to form the plural. However, some nouns do not. These nouns are irregular.
Some irregular plural nouns can be formed by changing the vowel or vowels in the word. For example, the singular noun "tooth" is made plural by changing the "o's" to "e's."
audio.notes: <visual: show word card "tooth" with a label above it that says "singular" and the word card "teeth" with a label above it that says "plural">

audio.transcription: Some irregular plural nouns can be formed by changing the "f" or "f-e" in the words to "v-e-s." For example, the plural form of the noun "life" is "lives."
audio.notes: <visual: show word card "life" with a label above it that says "singular" and the word card "lives" with a label above it that says "plural">

audio.transcription: Some irregular plural nouns do not follow any rules. For example, the plural form of the noun "person" is "people."
audio.notes: <visual: show word card "person" with a label above it that says "singular" and the word card "people" with a label above it that says "plural">

audio.transcription: Some words, such as "deer" do not change when they are plural.
audio.notes: <visual: show word card "deer" with a label above it that says "singular" and the word card "deer" with a label above it that says "plural">

audio.transcription: Do you know the plural form of these nouns?
Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 26, Lesson 9. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 26.
Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 8 in your Unit 26 Student Book. Whisper read the story “Alissa’s Tag Sale.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.

This is the sound-spelling card for the schwa sound. The schwa sound is pronounced “uh,” as in the second syllable of "carrot." This sound can be spelled with any vowel—a, e, i, o, u. Listen to the following words that have a schwa sound: "asleep," "camel," "family," "upon."
audio.notes: <visual: show the sound-spelling card for schwa>

audio.transcription: Blend Words: Let's blend some words to practice what we've learned. Read each word as your teacher taps on it. Say the word nice and loud.
Select two words from the list. Write a sentence for each word.

Listen to each word your teacher says. Write the word. If you need help, tap the sounds or use your sound boxes and counters to break up the word sound by sound. Then think about the letter that stands for each sound.
Let's start with these two words. Write the word supply.
Now write the word awake.
Finally, write this sentence: The scientist won an award for all she achieved.

Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about keeping food cool. First, look at these two pictures. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. icebox <pause>, drawer <pause>, refrigerator <pause>, freezer <pause>, shelf. Look at the picture of the refrigerator. What does a refrigerator do?
Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about keeping food cool. The word is innovation. An innovation is a new device, method, or idea.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, innovation>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words innovation and reliable>

audio.transcription: Now listen to “From Ice Pits and Ice Boxes to Refrigerators”
Do you have any wonderings or questions about keeping food cool? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 9 in your Unit 26 Student Book. The title of this text is "A New Kind of Pop!” Point to each word as you read the title with me: A New Kind of Pop! This informational text is about a girl who invented a new product.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this text: innovation. Innovation means “a new idea, or a better way of doing something.” The smart phone was an innovation that changed the way people communicate, or talk. Which invention has had the greatest effect on the way we live? Why was it an important innovation?
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story and the word, innovation>

audio.transcription: Read the text. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Find the name of the inventor that the text is mostly about.
How did Alina get the idea for her invention? Find the sentences that answer the question.
How did Alina develop her product? Summarize the process.
Would you describe Alina’s lollipop as an innovation? Why or why not?
You can reread this text during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.
Write to Deepen Comprehension: Describe an everyday object you would like to improve and explain how you would change it. <pause> Share your ideas with a partner before writing.

toc.title: Phonemic Awareness: Delete Initial and Final Sounds

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 26, Lesson 10. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 26.
Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 9 in your Unit 26 Student Book. Whisper read the story “A New Kind of Pop!” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Let's make a word ladder. I will give you a clue for each word to write on the word ladder.
This word names a big African cat with a mane.
Change lion to name a yellow fruit.
Change lemon to name a toy with wheels that you can pull.
Change wagon to name a large bird of prey. A famous football team has it as its mascot.
Change falcon to name something a cook or baker wears around his or her waist.
Change apron to name something you tie around a gift.
Now your teacher will ask you to read and write some words to check on your progress. Congratulations on all your hard work in Unit 26!

slides.title: Phonemic Awareness: Delete Initial and Final Sounds

audio.transcription: Listen as I say the following word: couch
Say the word couch without the beginning sound /k/. What's the new word? <pause> ouch
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words and sounds.
Now let's delete the ending sound of a word. Listen as I say the following word: date
Say the word date without the ending sound /t/. What's the new word? <pause> day
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words and sounds.

Let's review irregular plural nouns. Remember that a plural noun stands for "more than one of something." Many nouns add "s" or "es" to form the plural. However, some nouns do not. These nouns are irregular.
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "leaf" and the word "leaves">

audio.transcription: Build the irregular plural nouns for the following words.
Let's do some more work with this unit's high-frequency words. Look at the high-frequency words.
audio.notes: <visual: ago, government, half, machine, pair, quickly, scientist, thousand, understood, wait>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher reads a high-frequency word from the list. Point to the word. Read the word. Spell the the word aloud.

Now build each high-frequency word using letter cards. Then work with a partner. Take turns scrambling the letters in the words. Rebuild each word. Watch as your teacher models scrambling and rebuilding the word "half."
audio.notes: <visual: pocket chart with 3rd word spelled out with letter cards: half>
